Questions.QuestionText:
Calculate

  1. Box pleated valance, outside mount with 4" returns
  2. One full pleat in middle and ½ pleat on each corner
  3. Window: 60" wide x 48" long with 6" trim added to the window size
  4. 8 ft ceiling
  5. Hang at ceiling height on a velcro board
  6. Length to cover 3" of window glass
  7. Plain fabric
  8. Lining needed?

What are the steps to complete the calculations for this window treatment?
Questions.AnswerText:
Draw Â½" scale drawing on graph paper as your working copy.

  1. Outside mount means the valance has to come past the side width by 2" on each side.
  2. Window width = 4" return + 2" past + 6" trim + 60" window + 6" trim + 2" past + 4" return = 84" of space needed.
  3. Finished width needed does not include returns because they go back from the front of the treatment. Finished width = 2" past + 6" trim + 60" window + 6" trim + 2" past = finished width of treatment 76" (84" - 4" - 4" returns = 76").
  4. Box pleat header treatment needs one full pleat of 18" and a ½ pleat at each corner of the treatment to cover this area.
  5. 4" return + 2" past + 6" trim + 60" window + 6" trim + 2" past + 4" return = 84" of space needed + 18" full pleat in middle and +9" + 9" (½ pleats at each corner) = 84" + 18" + 9" + 9" = 120" + 6" selvage = (as valance is sewn together as 1 panel) width of fabric to make this treatment = 126" in total.
  6. Since fabric is 54" wide, you need to see how many cuts of 54" fabric you need to allow 126" of width.
  7. 126" divided by 54" = 2.3 cuts. Round up to the next full cut size = 3 cuts of 54" fabric to sew together to make the width needed for this treatment.

Length

  1. Hung at ceiling height and cover 3" of glass = 18" from ceiling to glass (12" wall + 6" trim) + 3" over glass = 21" finished length.
  2. This is not the amount to order. Box pleat style needs 12" to make hem and header.
  3. 21" finished length + 12" hem and header = 33" of fabric length x 3 cuts = 99" of fabric to order / 36" = 2.75 yards of fabric. Round up to 3 yards to order.
  4. Since there is no pattern, order the same amount of lining.
  5. This kind of treatment can look fuller and more finished with an interlining as well. For any treatment that has a large flat surface, it is recommended to add an interlining. An interlining for this treatment would also be the same amount as the regular lining and the fabric amount of 3 yards.
